entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 26 at 8:47AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Columbia, Suwannee and Gilchrist Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road. At 21.0 feet, Homes are surrounded on River Run Road in Suwannee County. Structures flood along Santa Fe Road west of Idaho Parkway in Columbia County.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:00 AM EDT Monday the stage was 19.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 17.4 feet Monday, September 02. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Suwannee, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 26 at 6:44AM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
At 642 AM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near Riverton, moving northeast at 40 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and half inch hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
This strong thunderstorm will be near... Eastern Riverton around 650 AM MDT. Boysen State Park around 700 AM MDT.
Other locations in the path of this storm include Shoshoni.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Wind River Basin; Lander Foothills

cap:parameter.value: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL IMPACT EAST CENTRAL FREMONT COUNTY THROUGH 730 AM MDT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 26 at 3:54AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary: THE HEAVIER RAINFALL FROM SUNDAY EVENING HAS ENDED. RAIN SHOWERS STILL PERSIST IN THE AREA, AND WILL LIKELY LINGER INTO MONDAY AFTERNOON. REPORTS OF THE TOTAL RAINFALL SO FAR ARE (ROUGHLY 36 HOURS) KETCHIKAN 2.54 INCHES, SHELTER COVE (AS OF 3 AM) 4.58 INCHES. HIGHER ELEVATIONS REPORTS FROM POWER STATIONS NEAR KETCHIKAN RANGE FROM 5 TO 9 INCHES OF RAIN. AS A RESULT THERE HAS BEEN AT LEAST ONE REPORTED LANDSLIDE IN KETCHIKAN.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 26 at 7:38AM EDT until August 26 at 11:30AM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Portions of DownEast, East Central, and North Central Maine, including the following counties, in DownEast Maine, Hancock. In East Central Maine, Penobscot. In North Central Maine, Piscataquis.
* WHEN...Until 1130 AM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways. Ponding of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 738 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. Between 0.2 and 0.5 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Bangor, Old Town, Bucksport, Dover-Foxcroft, Dexter, Newport, Guilford, Howland, Brownville Junction, Orono, Brewer, Hampden, Hermon, Corinth, Milo, Veazie, Dedham, Kenduskeag, Monson and East Corinth. - For flood safety visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Hancock, ME; Penobscot, ME; Piscataquis, ME

entry.title: Flash Flood Watch issued August 26 at 2:04AM MDT until August 27 at 12:00AM MDT by NWS Billings MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding and debris flows caused by locally heavy rainfall are possible over recent burn scars.
* WHERE...Portions of Montana, including the following areas, Powder River, Southern Big Horn and Southern Rosebud and north central Wyoming, including the following area, Sheridan Foothills.
* WHEN...Through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Locally heavy rainfall over recent burn scars is possible through this evening. Residents near recent burn scars should prepare for potential flooding impacts should heavy rainfall develop. Be sure to stay up to date with information from local authorities. Locally heavy rainfall could trigger flash flooding of streams, low-lying areas, and debris flows in and near recent wildfire burn scars.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - National Weather Service Meteorologists are forecasting locally heavy rainfall over the recent burn scars, which may lead to flash flooding and debris flows. Close to a half inch of rain has already fallen in portions of the watch area. Additional rainfall of a quarter to three quarters of an inch of rain is forecast, with locally heavier amounts possible. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Powder River; Southern Rosebud; Southern Big Horn; Sheridan Foothills

cap:parameter.value: FLASH FLOOD WATCH FOR RECENT BURN SCARS IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 26 at 2:03AM MDT until August 27 at 12:00AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of central and north central New Mexico, including the following areas, in central New Mexico, South Central Mountains. In north central New Mexico, East Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains and Southern Sangre de Cristo Mountains.
* WHEN...From noon MDT today through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 26 at 2:08AM CDT by NWS St Louis MO
entry.summary:
The St. Louis Clean Air Partnership has issued an air quality alert for the St. Louis metropolitan area from 10 AM this morning to 8 PM CDT this evening.
An Orange air quality forecast means that maximum ozone concentrations are expected to reach levels that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates. Ground- level ozone is an air contaminant which can cause breathing difficulties for children, older adults, as well as persons with respiratory problems.
Reducing outdoor physical activity is recommended. If it is a regularly scheduled work day you are urged to consider telecommuting, carpooling, or utilizing public transit. Avoid excessive idling and do not top off when refueling motor vehicles. The use of gasoline-powered lawn equipment should be reduced or postponed until late in the day.
For more information visit the St. Louis Clean Air Partnership at http://cleanair-stlouis.com/
For current Air Quality Index (AQI) values visit https://www.airnow.gov/
entry.cap:areaDesc: Madison; St. Clair; Monroe; St. Charles; Franklin; St. Louis; St. Louis City; Jefferson

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT FROM 10 AM THIS MORNING TO 8 PM CDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 25 at 9:26PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
A WEATHER FRONT IS BEGINNING TO EXIT THE SOUTHERN PANHANDLE SUNDAY NIGHT HAS RESULTED IN MODERATE TO HEAVY RAINFALL TOTALS OVER THE LAST 36 HOURS. REPORTS OF THE TOTAL RAINFALL SO FAR ARE (ROUGHLY 30 HOURS) KETCHIKAN 2.54 INCHES, SHELTER COVE (AS OF 4 PM) 2.75 INCHES. HIGHER ELEVATIONS REPORTS FROM POWER STATIONS NEAR KETCHIKAN RANGE FROM 5 TO 9 INCHES OF RAIN. AS A RESULT THERE HAS BEEN AT LEAST ONE REPORTED LANDSLIDE IN KETCHIKAN.
THE RAINS ARE ANTICIPATED TO DIMINISH TO A SHOWERY PATTERN IN THE NEXT FEW HOURS. SHOWERS WILL PERSIST INTO MONDAY AFTERNOON BEFORE BECOMING LESS FREQUENT.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 25 at 4:40PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
The Maryland Department of the Environment has issued a Code ORANGE Air Quality Alert Monday for Northeast Maryland.
A Code Orange Air Quality Alert means that air pollution concentrations within the region may become unhealthy for sensitive groups. Sensitive groups include children, people suffering from asthma, heart disease or other lung diseases and the elderly. The effects of air pollution can be minimized by avoiding strenuous activity or exercise outdoors.
For more information on ground-level ozone and fine particles visit the web site mde.maryland.gov/programs/air/AirQualityMonitoring/Pages/index.aspx.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 25 at 3:24PM CDT by NWS St Louis MO
entry.summary:
The St. Louis Clean Air Partnership has issued an air quality alert for the St. Louis metropolitan area from 10 AM to 8 PM CDT Monday.
An Orange air quality forecast means that maximum ozone concentrations are expected to reach levels that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates. Ground- level ozone is an air contaminant which can cause breathing difficulties for children, older adults, as well as persons with respiratory problems.
Reducing outdoor physical activity is recommended. If it is a regularly scheduled work day you are urged to consider telecommuting, carpooling, or utilizing public transit. Avoid excessive idling and do not top off when refueling motor vehicles. The use of gasoline-powered lawn equipment should be reduced or postponed until late in the day.
For more information visit the St. Louis Clean Air Partnership at http://cleanair-stlouis.com/
For current Air Quality Index (AQI) values visit https://www.airnow.gov/
entry.cap:areaDesc: Madison; St. Clair; Monroe; St. Charles; Franklin; St. Louis; St. Louis City; Jefferson

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT FROM 10 AM TO 8 PM CDT MONDAY

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 25 at 2:41PM CDT by NWS Kansas City/Pleasant Hill MO
entry.summary:
The Mid-America Regional Council has issued an Air Quality Alert...in effect for Monday August 26. Outdoor Air Quality Index, or AQI, values in excess of 100 are expected with ozone being the primary pollutant.
People and businesses are urged to avoid activities which lead to ozone formation. These activities include refueling vehicles or topping off when refueling idling vehicles unnecessarily and using gasoline powered lawn equipment. Positive activities include car pooling, biking to work, delaying or combining errands, and using water-based paints and cleaners.
When pollution levels are elevated, the Mid-America Regional Council recommends that individuals consider limiting strenuous outdoor physical activity to reduce the risk of adverse health effects. People who may be especially sensitive to the effects of elevated levels of pollutants include the very young, and those with pre- existing respiratory problems such as asthma or heart disease. Those with symptoms should consider consulting their personal physician.
For further information please see the Mid-America Regional Council air quality program website at http://www.airqkc.org.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Leavenworth; Wyandotte; Johnson; Platte; Clay; Jackson

cap:parameter.value: Air Quality Alert in effect for Monday August 26

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 25 at 2:07PM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
The Illinois Environmental Protection Agency has determined that an Air Pollution Action Day will be declared for the greater Chicago Metropolitan Area and is IN EFFECT UNTIL MIDNIGHT CDT MONDAY NIGHT.
An Air Pollution Action Day is declared when weather conditions are such that widespread ozone and or particulate levels are expected to be at or above the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups category of the Air Quality Index for multiple days.
Active children and adults, especially people with pulmonary or respiratory disease such as asthma, should limit prolonged outdoor activity.
Area residents are urged to reduce pollution levels. Air quality forecasts, current air quality, and tips on how you can reduce your emissions can be found at www.airnow.gov.
Media contact...Illinois EPA.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 23 at 11:33AM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
The following message is transmitted on behalf of the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division, and the Wyoming Department of Health.
* WHAT...Air Quality Alert for Wildfire Smoke.
* WHERE...Northwestern Wyoming and the upper Wind River Basin.
* WHEN...1 PM Friday Aug 23 through 1 PM Monday Aug 26.
* IMPACTS...Smoke from the Fish Creek Fire near Togwotee Pass continues to impact the region. Smoke could limit visibility at times, especially in the US Hwy 26 and 287 corridor over Togwotee Pass.
HEALTH INFORMATION...The Wyoming Department of Health recommends that the elderly, young children, and individuals with respiratory problems avoid excessive physical exertion and minimize outdoor activities during this time. Wildfire smoke is made up of a variety of pollutants, including particulate matter and ozone, which can cause respiratory health effects. Although these people are most susceptible to health impacts, the Department of Health also advises that everyone should avoid prolonged exposure to poor air quality conditions.
CURRENT CONDITIONS...The Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division offers near real-time air quality data for Wyoming's monitoring stations and health effects information to help the public interpret current conditions. Current air quality conditions across the state of Wyoming can be found at http://www.wyvisnet.com/.
